In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.
A bank clerk should be able to tell easily the difference between.........notes and counterfeit one

In each of the following sentences, there is one word underlined and one gap. From the list of words lettered A - D, choose the word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word and that will, at the same time, correctly fill the gap in the sentences.
Last night, Uncle Joe was blind drunk but this morning he is as.......as a judge
explanation:
The word "drunk" refers to a state of intoxication due to alcohol consumption. The opposite of being drunk is being sober, meaning not under the influence of alcohol. The word that best conveys the opposite meaning of "drunk" and fits the gap is "sober."
So, the corrected sentence reads: "Last night, Uncle Joe was blind drunk, but this morning he is as sober as a judge." It contrasts the intoxicated state from the previous night with the clear-headed and not under-the-influence state in the morning.

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences.
At a ...............of 200 kilometres an hour, the hurricane swept away everything in its path
explanation: The word"velocity"refers to the speed of something in a particular direction, especially when discussing motion in scientific or meteorological contexts. Hurricanes are typically measured in terms of their velocity, making this the most appropriate choice.

From the words lettered A to D below each of the following sentences, choose the word that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word.

Why should I retract my statement when it is nothing but the truth?

The doctor diagnosed the turmour as malignant

From the words lettered A to D below each of the following sentences, choose the word that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word.
In tropical Africa, mosquitoes are ubiquitous

From the words lettered A to D below each of the following sentences, choose the word that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word.
It soon became obvious that a confrontation was inevitable

From the words lettered A to D below each of the following sentences, choose the word that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word.
They insisted that the omission of my name had been inadvertent

From the words lettered A to D below each of the following sentences, choose the word that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word.
The police announced that they were yet to apprehend the criminals
explanation: The underlined word"apprehend"meansto catch or arrest someone, especially a criminal. The closest synonym among the options is"arrest", which meansto take someone into custody, usually by law enforcement. To prosecute refers to the legal process of trying someone in court, not the act of catching them. To charge means to formally accuse someone of a crime, which happens after an arrest.

text:
From the words lettered A to D below each of the following sentences, choose the word that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word.
He is easily recognizable because of a conspicuous birthmark on his face

From the words lettered A to D below each of the following sentences, choose the word that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word.
The fishing boat was imperilled by high winds, but it managed to reach port safely

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
Surprising, Musa turned..........the job

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
We have no choice..........to do what they demand

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
The committee has submitted its report...........the students' riot
explanation:
"The committee has submitted its report on the students' riot."
When presenting information that discusses a certain topic, then you are presenting information "on" that topic. "About" can also be used but it is less formal and not as precise as "on" If you make use of "about", you might not be suggesting that the central topic in the research is the "students' riot" but, there is a little bit of information about it in the report. This is why D. on is the correct answer.

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
The chairman told members that he was open..........suggestions

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
The policeman shot the escaping`robber..........the leg

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
For the management, your remarks amount to a slap........the face
explanation: aslapin theface. phrase. If you describe something that someone does as aslapin theface, you mean that it shocks or upsets you because it shows that they do not support you or respect you.

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
She does not remember.............to anyone at the part.

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
This portion is to be shared between.............

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
Joel is one of those fanatical sports fans......... about nothing else
explanation:
"Joel is one of those fanatical sports fans who talk about nothing else."
Sometimes, whenwho, that, whoseandwhichis used, confusion about the choice of appropriate verbs sets in. The law of concord provides thatwhowill refer to the noun or pronoun that comes before it and that noun or pronoun must become the subject. In the sentence above,whorefers to the "fanatical sports fans" which is now the subject and it attracts the plural verb "talk" (plural of talks). But this does not change the fact that "Joel talks about nothing else", however, Joel is one of those "fanatical sports fans who talk about nothing else."

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
I will see you ..........tomorrow

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
But for the night guard's vigilance, the factory.........burgled

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
No sooner............it started to rain
explanation:
"No sooner...than" is the appropriate correlative conjunction. This means that whenever you use "no sooner", the appropriate conjunction is "than".
The complete sentence would be: "No sooner had he arrived home than it started to rain."
The conjunction is used to indicate that one event happens immediately after another. In this case, the sentence means that as soon as he arrived home, it started to rain.

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
Hardly a day goes by........he doesn't think of her

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
Scarcely had I opened the door...........the dog came running in
explanation:
The phrase "scarcely had [subject] [past participle] when [event]" is a common grammatical structure used to indicate that one event happened immediately after another.
In this sentence, "Scarcely had I opened the door when the dog came running in," the word "scarcely" implies that hardly any time passed between opening the door and the dog running in. The correct conjunction to use in this structure is "when."

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
Several.............attended the two-day summit
explanation:
The phrase "heads of state" is the plural form of "head of state." In this context, you are referring to multiple individuals who hold the position of head of state. The word "heads" is the plural form of "head," and "of state" remains unchanged in the plural form.
So, the completed sentence is: "Several heads of state attended the two-day summit." This implies that multiple leaders or individuals holding the position of head of state were present at the summit.

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
You haven't seen this man before........?

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
I saw him again........last week
explanation:
The difference between "some time" and "sometime" lies in their usage and meaning:
Some time: This is a two-word phrase where "some" acts as an adjective describing "time." It refers to a certain period or span of time, often implying a long duration. For example, "It will take some time to finish the project."Sometime: This is a single word that functions as an adverb. It refers to an unspecified point in time, either in the past or future. For example, "Let's meet sometime next week."
Now, for the sentence "I saw him again........last week," the correct answer is D.sometime. The phrase "sometime" fits best because it indicates an unspecified period during the last week.

text:

She bought a ....handbag

explanation: It was the head boy that took the book away, wasn't it?

text:

.............., my father took me to England.

The teacher wanted to know if all our homework ........ submitted.

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
The man denied..........the company's property
explanation: The correct completion of the sentence is "stealing" because the verb "deny" is typically followed by a gerund (the -ing form of a verb) to indicate the action that is being denied.

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
The day I won a visa lottery was the..........day of my life

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
Ebiere invited.............to her birthday party
explanation: In sentence structure, we use 'Bola and I' in the subjective case while 'Bola and me' in the objective case. In this question, we have the subject which is, Ebiere. Therefore,  the receiver of the action is 'Bola and me'.

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
Adamu looked at his watch and said; '' it's high time we......home''
explanation: The expression "it's high time" is commonly followed by a past tense verb. In this context, it suggests that an action should have been done or started earlier. It highlights a sense of overdue or belated action. Therefore, the sentence "Adamu looked at his watch and said, 'it's high time we went home'" is grammatically correct.

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
She claims..........a ghost last night

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
We had better............now, or we'll miss the train

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
She...........the sleeping baby on the bed.
explanation:
VerbInfinitiveDefinitionPresentPastPastParticiplePresentParticiplelayto lay something downto put or placelay(s)laidlaidlayinglieto lieto rest or reclinelie(s)laylainlying
Illustration:
Using "lay" (to lay something down):Present: Shelaysthe book on the table every evening.Past: Yesterday, shelaidthe flowers on the grave.Past Participle: She haslaidout all the materials for the project.Present Participle: She islayingthe foundation for a new building.Using "lie" (to rest or recline):Present: The catliesin the sunbeam for hours.Past: Yesterday, the doglayon the sofa all day.Past Participle: The blanket hadlainuntouched for days.Present Participle: The patient islyingin bed recovering from surgery.

text:
From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
''.............we rather go home?'' he asked
explanation:
“Shouldn’t we rather go home?”
This phrasing is used to suggest or propose an action in a polite and somewhat rhetorical manner. We use "can't" when we are questioning someone's ability to do something. "Won't" is more about future actions and does not fit well in this context, especially with the use of the word "rather" in the sentence which suggests that the speaker is trying to make a suggestion rather than talk about future actions.

From the words or group of words lettered A to D, choose the word or group of words that best completes each of the following sentences.
Please can you...............money?
explanation:
''Borrow” means that you want to temporarily take something or you're letting someone take something that belongs to you; “borrowed” is the past tense.“Lend” means you’re giving something to someone or asking someone to give you an item you need; “lent” is the past tense.
Substitute “take” to check if “borrow” is the right word, and “give” to check if “lend” is the right word.
